meanings.def: recently produced or picked and not frozen, dried or preserved in tins or cans
examples: Is this milk fresh?
fresh bread/flowers/fish
Eat plenty of fresh fruit and vegetables.
Our chefs use only the freshest produce available.
fresh from something vegetables fresh from the garden
fresh off something Doesn't fruit taste a lot better fresh off the tree?
Mushrooms don't stay fresh for long.
Put it in the fridge to keep it fresh.
The croissants are nice and fresh.
Fresh fish is brought up from the coast on ice.
a toothpaste that leaves a nice fresh taste in your mouth
Let's go and get some fresh air (= go outside where the air is cooler).
Her hair smelled fresh and newly washed.
Horses should have fresh, clean water available at all times.
fresh tracks in the snow
a fresh wound
Let me write it down while it's still fresh in my mind.
The war is too recent and the memories are too fresh.
The park looks wonderful under a blanket of fresh snow.

meanings.def: new or different in a way that adds to or replaces something
examples: a fresh coat of paint
Could we order some fresh coffee?
The defence have found fresh evidence that could form the basis of an appeal.
This is the opportunity he needs to make a fresh start (= to try something new after not being successful at something else).
The government is said to be taking a fresh look at the matter.
The kids bring a wealth of fresh ideas with them.
I think it's time we tried a fresh approach.
They will lose no time in holding fresh elections.
Fresh towels are provided every day.
A few directors have launched new movies with fresh faces in the lead.
There is a shortage of fresh water on the island.
a fresh breeze
The winds are likely to get fresher towards the end of the day.
It's fresh this morning, isn't it?
He looked fresh and neat in a clean white shirt.
a collection of summer dresses in fresh colours
a fresh complexion
Regular facials help to keep the skin looking clean and fresh.
The yellow paint makes the kitchen look much fresher.
Regular exercise will help you feel fresher and fitter.
I managed to sleep on the plane and arrived feeling as fresh as a daisy.

meanings.def: having just come from a particular place; having just had a particular experience
examples: fresh out of something students fresh out of college
fresh from something fresh from her success at the Olympic Games
fresh off something The singer is fresh off a successful world tour.

meanings.def: rude and too confident in a way that shows a lack of respect for somebody or a sexual interest in somebody
examples: Don't get fresh with me!

meanings.def: clean air breathed in after being indoors or in a dirty atmosphere
examples: We'll get a breath of fresh air at lunchtime.
I'm going outside for a breath of fresh air.

meanings.def: a person, thing or place that is new and different and therefore interesting and exciting
examples: The new secretary is a breath of fresh air.

meanings.def: new members or employees, especially young ones, with new ideas or ways of doing things
examples: This company badly needs to bring in some fresh blood.

meanings.def: to make somebody feel positive, especially when they thought that they had no chance of achieving something

idioms.def: clean air breathed in after being indoors or in a dirty atmosphere
examples: We'll get a breath of fresh air at lunchtime.
I'm going outside for a breath of fresh air.

idioms.def: a person, thing or place that is new and different and therefore interesting and exciting
examples: The new secretary is a breath of fresh air.

idioms.def: new members or employees, especially young ones, with new ideas or ways of doing things
examples: This company badly needs to bring in some fresh blood.

idioms.def: to make somebody feel positive, especially when they thought that they had no chance of achieving something

examples: fresh-baked bread

meanings.def: having recently finished a supply of something
examples: Sorry, we're fresh out of milk.

idioms.def: having recently finished a supply of something
examples: Sorry, we're fresh out of milk.
